docs.lead_paragraph: DEPENDING on the weather for the rest of the winter, highway crews will spread 10 to 15 million tons of salt to melt ice and snow on highways in the United States and Canada. But the salt will also corrode the metal on bridges, guardrails and steel reinforcing bars, as well as break down the concrete itself and damage the vehicles that travel those roads. Now transportation researchers think they have found a practical replacement de-icer that is far less corrosive than salt, and only about half as corrosive as tap water. In some cases, it may actually inhibit rust. It is made from ordinary limestone and from whey, the stuff that Miss Muffet ate while sitting on her tuffet.

headline.main: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Safety; Whey (Hold the Curds) For Icy Winter Streets

docs.lead_paragraph: Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, the largest health maintenance organization in Massachusetts, has been placed into receivership by a state judge after it disclosed that accounting errors had caused it to underestimate 1999 losses by millions of dollars. Tuesday night, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court put the H.M.O. under the supervision of the state's insurance commissioner, Linda Ruthardt, at the request of Thomas Reilly, the state attorney general.

headline.main: Health Insurer Put In State Receivership

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Democratic presidential debate last night in Durham, N.H., involving Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as recorded by The New York Times: Q. Mr. Bradley, has Mr. Gore ever taken a vote of yours or a quote out of context? MR. BRADLEY A vote or a quote? Yes. Q. Mr. Gore, has Mr. Bradley ever taken a vote or a quote out of yours, out of context? MR. GORE I haven't complained about any. Q. The question was has he. . . . MR. GORE I don't know that the answer is no, but if you want a no, I'll give you a no. Q. O.K. Well then Mr. Bradley, being that you think Mr. Gore has taken a vote or a quote out of context, choose one that you think was particularly offensive.

headline.main: Excerpts From Comments by Gore and Bradley at Forum for Candidates

docs.lead_paragraph: United Way of America owes its imprisoned former president, William V. Aramony, the full $4.2 million in his deferred compensation plan because the plan did not include a clause forfeiting the money if Mr. Aramony committed a felony, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of United States District Court in Manhattan ruled, however, that United Way can withhold $2.02 million in salary, investigative costs and interest that Mr. Aramony owes the national organization, which he ran for 19 years. She also ruled that Mr. Aramony is not entitled to legal fees due the lawyer who won the case, Dennis Houdek of Flacone, Houdek & Curd in Manhattan.

headline.main: Ex-Chief of United Way Owed $4.2 Million

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's emergency rooms, nursing homes and employers are facing down an odious flu that came late and with a vengeance, bringing with it a cousin -- a cough and ache-producing, endlessly protracted bug that is not really flu at all but is perhaps even more miserable. From lower Manhattan to the farthest reaches of Queens, hospitals are reporting that their emergency rooms are flooded with people complaining of high fevers, hacking coughs, breathing troubles and dehydration. A shortage of vaccine could make matters worse, and doctors say New Yorkers are not overly fond of the shots anyway.

headline.main: Flu Cases Jam the E.R. and Empty the Office

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore, 1,125 miles apart, argued today about the virtues of experience and accused each other of having a vision too limited to deal with problems that concern most Americans. ''Only those who have never left Washington have missed the lessons of the last decade,'' Mr. Bradley told an audience of 400 here. The audience first giggled and then applauded at the obvious reference to Mr. Gore, who has held office in Washington since 1977.

headline.main: BRADLEY AND GORE RENEW THE BATTLE

byline.original: By ADAM CLYMER with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

docs.lead_paragraph: Cindy Herdrich, a part-time legal secretary, said she suspected all along that the sharp pain in her lower abdomen was appendicitis. But Lori Pegram, a doctor at her husband's H.M.O. in Bloomington, Ill., did not agree. Fourteen painful days later, the health maintenance organization finally authorized an ultrasound scan. Too late. Ms. Herdrich's appendix ruptured. She contracted peritonitis and required emergency surgery.

headline.main: Under Legal Attack, H.M.O.'s Face a Supreme Court Test

docs.lead_paragraph: Humana Inc., the troubled managed-care company, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $400 million to $500 million in the fourth quarter, the latest in a series of charges and one-time items. The latest charge will result in a loss for 1999, wiping out operating profits projected at 63 cents a share. The write-off reflects disappointing results from Humana's 1997 purchase of the Physicians Corporation of America for $270 million in cash and $130 million in debt. Humana indicated that it would lower the value assigned to good will in the purchase, which suggests that the price, which was considered low at the time, was still too high.

headline.main: Humana Quarterly Charge Will Result in Loss in 1999

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One key factor in the cost and potential value of covering the 44 million Americans with no or inadequate health insurance was omitted from your Dec. 27 editorial ''Two Visions on Health Care.''
